subject: Productivity
title: The Hawthorne Studies
description: A 60-second lesson on The Hawthorne Studies.

hook.text: Researchers changed the lighting in a factory. Productivity rose. They dimmed it. Productivity still rose.

buildup.text: The Hawthorne studies ran from 1924 to 1932 at a Western Electric plant near Chicago.

discovery.text: Elton Mayo concluded that attention itself boosted performance. Workers responded to being noticed.

twist.text: The Hawthorne effect became famous, but later analysis questioned Mayo's methods and conclusions.

climax.text: Regardless of the debate, the studies launched human relations in management. People aren't just machines.

punchline.text: Paying attention to workers mattered more than lighting.

quiz.question: What did the Hawthorne studies suggest about worker productivity?
options: Attention and being noticed boosted performance
